stem: The emergency department nurse is triaging a client of child-bearing age with abdominal pain. Based on the documentation, match each finding to the correct clinical concern.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: Patient: Lena, 24 years old. Reports sharp, stabbing pain in her lower right quadrant (RLQ). Last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. At 14:00, client feels dizzy; heart rate is 118. Reports referred pain in her right shoulder.

tabs.title: Obstetric Ultrasound & hCG Tracker
tabs.content:
AssessmentResultSignificance
Serum beta-hCG2,500 mIU/mLPositive Pregnancy
Transvaginal UltrasoundEmpty Uterus; Mass in Fallopian TubeExtrauterine Pregnancy
Peritoneal FluidFree fluid noted in pouch of DouglasPotential Hemorrhage

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 90/58 (Low), HR 118 (High). Client is pale and cool to the touch.

rows.text: Referred pain to the right shoulder (Kehr's sign)
Empty uterus on ultrasound with a positive pregnancy test

rationale.correct: Classical signs of ectopic pregnancy include unilateral pain and an empty uterus with high hCG. Signs that the tube has ruptured, leading to internal bleeding, include shoulder pain (diaphragmatic irritation) and signs of hypovolemic shock.
clinicalPearls: Any woman of child-bearing age with abdominal pain gets a pregnancy test (hCG).
Shoulder pain (Kehr's sign) indicates that blood is irritating the phrenic nerve.
A ruptured ectopic pregnancy is a surgical emergency.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking shoulder pain is 'normal' in early pregnancy.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Shoulder pain in the presence of abdominal pain and a positive pregnancy test is an ABSOLUTE RED FLAG for rupture.

mnemonic.title: Ectopic Empty
mnemonic.expansion: Empty uterus on scan + High hCG = Ectopic (Dangerous).
